title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: No sooner was Eleanor convinced of Nanny's innocence,  than she insisted on accompanying Dr. Murray and Mr. Grant to Gowanbank.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: Poor Nanny ! she is beyond the reach of all that compunction and sorrow could suggest; but I shall accompany you to Gowanbank myself Meanwhile  this is no time to speak, for I must act.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: " Now, where can he be going ? " cried Eleanor ; " Sir Alfred must have mistaken his way, for that road lead.s only to Gowanbank, and one or two wretched little cottages.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: The scene she had lately gone through at Gowanbank, the panic which had seized her about the Irishman, and the confusion of having intruded  so unexpectedly on Sir Alfred, altogether combined  to agitate her nerves so powerfully, that every attempt  to articulate only ended in a convulsive quiver of the lips.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: A HEAVY fall of snow had come on while Matilda remained at Gowanbank, but the weather now cleared up into the very beau ideal of a winter day — bright, cold, and clear.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: When Matilda swung open a little white gate, which led through the garden to Gowanbank, and saw the whole landscape brilliantly lighted up with a sheet of sunshine^, she remembered her first visits there in autumn ^ when the placid old w^onian always met her with a smiling welcome at the door, and Martha used to suspend  her labours, with many expressions of pleasure, and gratitude for the kindness she shewed them in coming.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: This is not the first time, I assure you all, that my cousin  has been reduced to beggary ; for she attacked me two days ago to assist in making out a trousseau for the daughter of that old woman who lives at Gowanbank, and who was married, I believe, this morning.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: " Dr. Murray !" replied Eleanor, starting and colouring,  " it was impossible to hear all you told me yesterday  without being deeply affected, and I lost not an hour in sending my housekeeper, Mrs. Gordon, to Gowanbank.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: When they approached within sight of Gowanbank, however, he seemed at once to call his mind back from the pleasures of meditation to the business and duty of the present hour.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: Matilda having understood that the unfortunate Nanny was at once removed from Barnard Castle, and carried without warning or preparation into the presence of her aged mother, felt anxiously desirous to ascertain how the good old woman had borne so sudden a shock, and she determined to lose no time in making her inquiries at Gowanbank, with a hope of ascertaining some way in which the sorrows of that once cheerful cottage could be mitigated.

title: Modern society;
author: Sinclair, Catherine
snippet: William Grey continued his attendance at Gowanbank, notwithstanding the conscientious  discouragement with which she persevered in avoiding him ; and could he have known how great was the effort which it caused her to do so, his estimation  of her heart, as well as her principles, must have
